**" If I Said You Had a Beautiful Body Would You Hold It Against Me"** is a
song written by David Bellamy, and recorded by American country music duo [The
Bellamy Brothers](/wiki/The_Bellamy_Brothers "The Bellamy Brothers"). It was
released in March 1979 as the second single from the album _[The Two and
Only](/wiki/The_Two_and_Only "The Two and Only")_. The song became their first
number 1 hit on the _[Billboard magazine](/wiki/Billboard_magazine "Billboard
magazine")_ [Hot Country Singles](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country Songs")
chart and their second number one overall, after their 1976 pop hit "[Let Your
Love Flow](/wiki/Let_Your_Love_Flow "Let Your Love Flow")". The title as shown
on the original single was **" If I Said You Have a Beautiful Body Would You
Hold It Against Me"**,[1] but on the album and subsequent releases, the title
is shown as "... Had ...".

##
Story[[edit](/w/index.php?title=If_I_Said_You_Had_a_Beautiful_Body_Would_You_Hold_It_Against_Me&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Story")]

"If I Said You Had a Beautiful Body ..." derived its [double
entendre](/wiki/Double_entendre "Double entendre") title from a [Groucho
Marx](/wiki/Groucho_Marx "Groucho Marx") line. Songwriter David Bellamy told
country music journalist Tom Roland that he regularly watched Marx's program,
_[You Bet Your Life](/wiki/You_Bet_Your_Life "You Bet Your Life")_ , where
Marx sometimes used the quote while interviewing an attractive female
contestant, then shake his cigar and raise his eyebrows to elicit a
reaction.[2] The comment stuck in Bellamy's head as a possible hook line for a
song.

The song earned its first success in [Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland
"Northern Ireland")[3] before becoming a hit in the United States. The song
was also a minor hit on Top 40 stations, peaking at No. 39 on the Billboard
Hot 100.

In a 2003 issue, _[Country Weekly](/wiki/Country_Weekly "Country Weekly")_
magazine named it the number 1 country pick-up line of all time.

## Re-
recording[[edit](/w/index.php?title=If_I_Said_You_Had_a_Beautiful_Body_Would_You_Hold_It_Against_Me&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Re-recording")]

On their 2005 album _[Angels& Outlaws, Vol.
1](/w/index.php?title=Angels_%26_Outlaws,_Vol._1&action=edit&redlink=1 "Angels
& Outlaws, Vol. 1 \(page does not exist\)")_, The Bellamy Brothers re-recorded
this song with [Dolly Parton](/wiki/Dolly_Parton "Dolly Parton"). This
rendition peaked at number 60 on the country charts, giving the Bellamy
Brothers their first chart entry since "Not" in 1994.

## Britney Spears
controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=If_I_Said_You_Had_a_Beautiful_Body_Would_You_Hold_It_Against_Me&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Britney Spears controversy")]

In 2011, the Brothers criticized pop singer [Britney
Spears](/wiki/Britney_Spears "Britney Spears")'s song "[Hold It Against
Me](/wiki/Hold_It_Against_Me "Hold It Against Me")" for sounding similar to
**" If I Said You Had A Beautiful Body Would You Hold It Against Me"**. In a
statement, David Bellamy said "professionally, well, in all honesty, we feel
completely ripped off. Where's the originality?"[4] The Bellamy Brothers'
attorney Christopher E. Schmidt stated that "[it] becomes somewhat uncanny if
you simply double the beat of the Bellamy Brothers' song and match it up with
Britney's version" and pointed out that it was not the first time that
songwriters [Max Martin](/wiki/Max_Martin "Max Martin") and [Lukasz "Dr. Luke"
Gottwald](/wiki/Dr._Luke "Dr. Luke") were accused of [copyright
infringement](/wiki/Copyright_infringement "Copyright infringement").[5] On
March 2, 2011, Max Martin, Dr. Luke, [Bonnie McKee](/wiki/Bonnie_McKee "Bonnie
McKee"), and Mathieu "Billboard" Jomphe, all of whom wrote "Hold It Against
Me", filed a lawsuit against the Bellamy Brothers for defamation and libel
because of the accusations,[6] but the Brothers apologized and the case was
dismissed on August 11, 2011. The Brothers released a statement that said,
"The Bellamy Brothers apologise to Dr. Luke and Max Martin for the Bellamys'
public statements and any false impressions suggested by the statements on
their website that Dr. Luke and Max Martin copy the works of others."[7]
